awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Linking Chemistry to the Mechanics of Dynamic Hydrogel Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description

Soft hydrogel interfaces are essential for high-technology applications, from synthetic tissues and medical adhesives, to commodity products, such as contact lenses. However, the majority of hydrogels are limited to static properties, hindering advanced material functions. This award supports fundamental research that aims to advance knowledge on how to control dynamic interfaces enabled by dynamic bonds in hydrogels, and relate macroscopic to microscopic mechanical behavior. The project takes advantage of expert resources and facilities at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where the PI and his collaborators will focus on synthesizing new dynamic hydrogels and characterizing their mechanical properties. The resources available in soft matter at MIT will play a critical role in synthesis and characterization of these hydrogels. In addition to advancing scientific knowledge, successful development of dynamic hydrogels is expected to afford a platform for new biomaterials to advance national health. New lasting collaborations will be developed between the PI and hosts, which will strengthen partnerships between the University of Kentucky (UK) and MIT, leading to a stronger program in soft materials at UK.

Technical Description
Soft polymer interfaces underpin many important applications, from hydrogel medical adhesives and synthetic tissues to contact lenses. However, they are largely limited to materials with static properties, hindering advanced functions where smart, responsive, or transient interfaces are desirable. The proposed research aims to advance our knowledge on how to control interfaces of soft hydrogels with dynamic properties, enabled by ligand-metal crosslinking dynamics. We expect interfacial behavior to be governed by the time-dependent formation of bonds, near-surface viscoelasticity of the bulk material, and the molecular architecture and composition of the gel relative to the crosslinking dynamics. To address this hypothesis, the PI will cultivate lasting collaborations with experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in hydrogel synthesis with metal-ligand crosslinking and non-Newtonian mechanical characterization. As part of this project, the PI and a student will be trained in necessary synthesis methods, as well as unique rheological methods. The results obtained on the chemistry and macroscale rheology will be coupled with interfacial mechanics experiments to develop a link between the chemistry and mechanics of dynamic hydrogel interfaces. The skills gained by the PI will become extremely valuable as new chemistry and molecular organizations are explored to expand the versatility and control of dynamic hydrogel properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Hydrogels are important for a range of engineered systems, including synthetic biomaterials and wound dressings to wet adhesives and contact lenses. Transiently crosslinked hydrogels offer tunable viscoelastic properties and potential healing capabilities; however, an understanding of the relationships between material properties and adhesion is still being developed. This fellowship aimed to train one student from the University of Kentucky (UK) in the development of mussel-inspired, transiently crosslinked hydrogels by visiting the group of Prof. Holten-Andersen at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). Upon synthesizing these materials, the team sought to explore their mechanical and adhesive properties.

Intellectual merit: The research resulting from this fellowship demonstrates how crosslinking modalities in a hydrogel, transiently crosslinked with mussel-inspired metal-ligand coordination bonds, affects macroscopically measured adhesion. In particular, we have shown how the amount of tris-bonds in a hydrogel network relates to the adhesive pull-off strength to difference material surfaces. This is important since the crosslinking modalities also affect the mechanical properties of the hydrogels. These observations are now enabling the exploration of bonding on the mechanical properties and adhesion when using different solvents and ligands.

Broader impacts: This fellowship helped fund a graduate student starting at their first year in Chemical and Materials Engineering at UK. It offered the student a unique opportunity to travel to and work at MIT over one summer, while the PI joined for part of the trip. Although two trips were planned, one had to be cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic. The student learned how to prepare transient, mussel-inspired hydrogels, and is continuing to work with these materials for the remainder of their doctoral training. The advances from this research provide guidelines on designing fully transient hydrogels for applications in healthcare and adhesives, where both mechanical and interfacial properties play a critical role. Moreover, the team at UK has expanded to include new collaborators in Kentucky; hence this ESPCoR fellowship has enabled new research directions for other researchers in the Commonwealth of Kentucky.


Last Modified: 01/03/2022
Modified by: Jonathan T Pham
